Date of the article's publication, indicating the most up-to-date assessment of public perception of Trump's Gaza deal and economic policies as of mid-October 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe during which polls were conducted after the Gaza ceasefire deal was announced, showing initial public reactions that were not sustained.

keyTakeAways: Americans show little enthusiasm for Trump’s handling of the Gaza ceasefire deal, despite its international prominence.
Trump’s approval ratings on the economy have deteriorated significantly, with disapproval reaching a high of 62% on inflation and cost of living, and overall economic approval at a second-term low.
Public trust in Trump’s leadership has not improved due to the Gaza deal, suggesting that economic concerns outweigh foreign policy achievements.
Polling data indicates that Americans prioritize domestic economic issues over international affairs, with only 4% citing international events as the top national issue.
A wait-and-see attitude is evident among the public, reflecting past failures of Middle East peace agreements (e.g., Biden’s ceasefire that lasted only two months).
Recent economic indicators show growing pessimism: only 32% expect economic improvement and 31% expect wage increases over the next year.
The percentage of employed Americans not worried about job loss has dropped to 52%, signaling increasing economic anxiety.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Despite the announcement of a Gaza ceasefire deal that some believed would bolster Donald Trump’s global standing and possibly earn him a Nobel Peace Prize, public sentiment in the United States shows little enthusiasm. Polling data from AP-NORC and CNBC indicates that while Trump’s approval on the Gaza issue slightly increased, it remained balanced with disapproval, and his overall approval rating on domestic economic issues has reached a low point, with 62% disapproving of his handling of inflation and cost of living. Public skepticism is further fueled by declining confidence in the economy, with only 32% expecting economic improvement and 31% expecting wage growth. The article concludes that Americans are prioritizing economic concerns over foreign policy achievements, reflecting a broader trend where domestic issues—especially inflation and job security—outweigh international developments, and that past failures of peace agreements reinforce a wait-and-see attitude toward the Gaza deal’s longevity.
title: Americans shrug at Trump’s Gaza deal, as economic fears reign
